subject: Re: [junit] Testing Getters and Setters - Achieving near-100% code coverage
msgSnippet: ... Yes. Getters and setters are easy to test. Test them! You ll be surprised how many bugs you ll find in methods that are supposedly too simple to fail.
messageBody:
y153446 wrote:
> I'm interested in best practices around automated unit testing of
> getters and setters for organizations striving for near-100% code
> coverage.
> Is anyone actually striving for near-100% code coverage?
>

Yes. Getters and setters are easy to test. Test them! You'll be
surprised how many bugs you'll find in methods that are supposedly too
simple to fail.

There are a few cases where you really can't test stuff. In particular
Sometimes you just have to have unreachable code. For instance, I
sometimes find myself implementing an interface such as
java.util.Iterator in a private inner class. My private implementation
may never call remove() but I still need to implement that method anyway
to fulfill the contract of Iterator. Normally I just make the method
throw an exception, in case I'm wrong and something does call it.
However, there's just no way to reach it to test it (nor is there any
need to do so since this code will never run.) But aside from a few
weird cases like that, all code should be tested or deleted.
